School of Chemical Engineering, Pusan National University Busan 46241 Republic of Korea 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Supported bimetallic catalysts are widely used for carbon nanotube (CNT) synthesis, yet the effects of impregnation procedure remain underexplored. Here, we investigated how the sequence of metal impregnation affects CNT synthesis. We prepared cobalt-molybdenum (Co-Mo) bimetallic catalysts on alumina supports via co- and stepwise impregnation, then compared their CNT synthesis performance under identical conditions. Stepwise-impregnated catalysts exhibited higher carbon yields than those prepared by co-impregnation. Notably, impregnating Mo after Co achieved the highest yield despite the lowest BET surface area. Synchrotron X-ray diffraction and visible/UV-Raman spectroscopy revealed that only this catalyst contained Al2(MoO4)3 with a MoO4 structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy clarified the surface chemistry: the catalyst with the highest CNT productivity exposed Mo entirely as Mo6 + in Al2(MoO4)3 and CoMoO4, whereas the others contained both Mo4+ and Mo6+. The MoOx species like Al2(MoO4)3 is known to suppress Co sintering during CNT synthesis, delaying catalyst deactivation and enhancing the carbon yield. Moreover, an inverse relationship was observed between carbon yield and the CoMoO4 content. This is attributed to the consumption of catalytically active Co during CoMoO4 formation, which reduces active sites for CNT growth. ICP-OES further confirmed higher Co and Mo loadings for stepwise catalysts, contributing to superior catalyst performance. The extent of CoMoO4 formation strongly depended on the metal introduction sequence. This trend is illustrated by considering the relationship between the point of zero charge of support and the pH of the metal precursor solutions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon nanotubes Catalyst Stepwise impregnation Point of zero charge Metal ion adsorption Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to their exceptional mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have extensive applications in energy storage devices, composites, electrode, and sensors [1–4]. Their one-dimensional structure and high aspect ratio not only contribute to outstanding properties but also make them well-suited for materials and devices across various industries. For broader implementation, mass production is essential. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is the most popular method for mass production, as it offers distinct advantages in scalability and process control. In CVD-based CNT synthesis, transition metals such as cobalt (Co), nickel (Ni), and iron (Fe) are used as catalysts. Catalyst properties, such as metal composition and particle size, influence the CNT synthesis results [5–7]. Hence, extensive research has been conducted to develop improved catalysts. Bimetallic catalysts allow for the exploration of new catalytic possibilities that surpass those achievable with conventional monometallic catalysts. By appropriately selecting metal species and optimizing their composition, the synergistic effects of the two metals can enhance key catalytic properties, such as activity, selectivity, and stability, that were previously unattainable [7–11]. For example, Alvarez et al. reported that coexistence of Co and Mo can promote the growth of single-walled CNTs (SWCNTs) via CO decomposition [7]. He et al. showed that copper (Cu) can enhance reducibility of Fe, thereby lowering the synthesis temperature of SWCNTs and improving yields [8]. Loebick et al. reported the successful synthesis of sub-nanometer (< 0.7 nm) SWCNTs diameter using CoMn catalyst [9]. Bachilo et al. reported that SWCNTs with narrow chirality distribution can be synthesized by synergistic effect of Co and Mo in the process of CNT synthesis step [10]. Since catalyst properties are significantly determined during the preparation process, it is crucial to comprehend how these catalysts are synthesized. Bimetallic catalysts for CNT synthesis are generally prepared by co-impregnation in which both metal precursors are introduced simultaneously [5,7,10–13]. While co-impregnation is straightforward and scalable, it has limitations. During impregnation, metal ion adsorption onto a porous oxide support is strongly influenced by pH of the solution and the point of zero charge (PZC) of the support [14]. In the co-impregnation of two metal species, these adsorption dynamics become more complex and challenging to control, potentially affecting the uniformity and distribution of the metal nanoparticles on the support. Meanwhile, stepwise impregnation introduces metal precursors sequentially, enabling exact control over the dispersity of the metal phase and the interaction between the metals and the support. Many studies have shown that carefully manipulating how metal ions interact with the support through this method can make catalysts with different structures and performance compared to that prepared by co-impregnation [15–17] Jing et al. reported that impregnating Ni after Co on MgO improved metal dispersion, resulting in smaller Ni particles and stronger interactions between impregnated Co and MgO support. This enhanced interaction led to higher activity for CO2 reforming and improved stability [15]. Chen et al. demonstrated more efficient hydrodesulfurization of thiophene when Mo was impregnated after Co on alumina (Al2O3) [16]. Li et al. reported that stepwise impregnation—depositing Mo and W first, followed by V—enhanced the simultaneous Hg(0) oxidation and NO reduction activity of molybdate modified V-based SCR catalysts by up to ∼20 %p relative to co-impregnation or the reverse sequence [17]. Despite its advantages in adjusting metal dispersion and phase formation, stepwise impregnation has been rarely studied in CNT synthesis. In this research, we prepared catalysts using stepwise impregnation and synthesized CNTs under identical conditions, comparing their performance to that of co-impregnated catalysts. The stepwise-impregnated catalysts exhibited higher carbon yields than their co-impregnated catalyst. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy, synchrotron X-ray diffraction (SXRD) analyses, and XPS revealed that the sequence of metal precursor impregnation affects the formation of distinct Mo species, which consequently explains the observed differences in carbon yield. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation (NH4)6Mo7O24‧4 H2O (98 %, Daejung chemical and metals, Siheung-si, Republic of Korea), Co(NO3)2‧6 H2O (98.0 %, Matsugaki chemical industries, Oskak, Japan), and Al2O3 (99 %, 32–63 μm, Alfa Aesar, Haverhill, MA, USA) were used as Mo precursor, Co precursor, and support respectively, to prepare catalysts. The phase composition of the Al₂O₃ support was analyzed by XRD, and the results confirmed that the support is γ-Al2O3 (Figure S1). The bimetallic catalysts are composed of 15 wt% of Co, 15 wt% of Mo, and 70 wt% of Al2O3. To provide a control group for the bimetallic catalysts, monometallic catalysts were prepared. Owing to the different atomic masses (Co 58.93 g/mol, Mo 95.96 g/mol), this design gives Co: Mo atomic ratio ≈ 1.63:1. The equal 15 wt% per metal was selected to isolate the effects of impregnation sequence and Co-Mo interactions. Monometallic catalysts consisted of 15 wt% of the corresponding metal and 85 wt% of Al2O3 for comparison. Because Co oxide is the active species for CNT growth, keeping the Co loading at 15 wt% enables a fair comparison with bimetallic catalysts. The detailed catalyst preparation by co-impregnation was as follows: (1) To prepare 1 g of the catalyst, 0.27678 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24‧4 H2O (molecular weight = 1235.86 g/mol) and 0.73987 g of Co(NO3)2‧6 H2O (molecular weight = 291.03 g/mol) were simultaneously dissolved in 50 mL of deionized (DI) water under ambient conditions. (2) The Al2O3 support was impregnated with this solution for 1 h at room temperature, followed by drying at 170 °C for 3 h. (3) The obtained solid was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h in a horizontal furnace in open air. This sample is denoted as CoMo. The other two bimetallic catalysts were also prepared using the same amounts of precursors. The bimetallic catalyst in which Mo was impregnated prior to Co was prepared as follows: (1) The Al2O3 support was impregnated in aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24‧4 H2O at room temperature for 1 h and then dried at 170 °C for 3 h under ambient conditions. (2) The resulting solid was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h in open air. (3) This calcined solid was impregnated in an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2‧6 H2O at room temperature for 1 h, followed by drying at 170 °C for 3 h under ambient conditions. (4) The material was calcined again at 600 °C for 5 h in open air. The catalyst made using this procedure is referred to as step-MoCo. The bimetallic catalyst in which Co was impregnated prior to Mo was prepared as follows: (1) The Al2O3 support was impregnated in aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2‧6 H2O at room temperature for 1 h and then dried at 170 °C for 3 h under ambient conditions. (2) The resulting solid was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h in open air. (3) This calcined solid was impregnated in an aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24‧4 H2O at room temperature for 1 h, followed by drying at 170 °C for 3 h under ambient conditions. (4) The material was calcined again at 600 °C for 5 h in open air. The catalyst made using this procedure is referred to as step-CoMo. The preparation of monometallic catalysts followed the same impregnation, drying, and calcination steps and conditions as those used for the bimetallic catalysts. A catalyst containing only Co or Mo is referred to as ‘Co’ or ‘Mo’, respectively. To investigate how pH of metal precursor solution affects adsorption behavior and distribution of metal ions, the pH of each solution and the PZC of the Al2O3 support was measured using a pH meter (HI 6221, HANNA instruments) which was calibrated before every set of measurements with standard buffer solutions at pH 4.0, 7.0, and 10.0. All measurements were performed at room temperature. Each sample was gently stirred during measurements to ensure homogeneity, and the pH value was determined after allowing the electrode to stabilize for an additional 5 min. The pH values of Co, Mo, and Co–Mo precursor solution were 5.7, 5.0, and 4.7, respectively. To determine the PZC of the support, we used the equilibrium pH at high surface loading (EpHL) method. This method utilizes the buffer effect of hydroxyl groups on the oxide surface, where high surface loading leads to a pH shift in the metal-free solution toward the oxide’s PZC across a wide pH range [18]. Al2O3 (208 m2/g) was added to pH-controlled solutions (pH 1–13) to have surface loading of 30000 m2/L. The surface loading was calculated using the following equation: Surface loading m 2 ∕ L = ( w support [ g ] ) × ( specific surface area of support [ m 2 / g ] ) ( Solution volume L ) where w support are the support weights. The pH of solutions was adjusted by using HCl and NaOH. Then, the suspension was shaken for 20 h, after which the initial (pHi) and final (pHf) pH values were recorded using the forementioned pH meter. Plotting the pHf versus pHi and applying a zeroth-order fit to the linear region between pH 2 and 9 yielded a PZC of 8.6 for the support (Figure S2). 2.2 CNT synthesis The CNT synthesis procedure was conducted similarly to the previous study [19]. A ceramic boat with 0.01 g of catalyst was placed in a quartz tube inside a horizontal furnace. The temperature was ramped from room temperature to 690 ℃ (the CNT synthesis temperature) at a rate of 15 ℃/min under a flow of N2 (500 sccm). Upon reaching 690 ℃, the gas flow was changed to H2 (75 sccm), C2H4 (75 sccm), and N2 (350 sccm), and the reaction was maintained for 1 h to synthesize the CNTs. After the synthesis, the gas flow was switched back to N2 (500 sccm), and the system was cooled to room temperature. The carbon yield was calculated using the following equation: Carbon yield % = 100 × ( W after ) − ( W before ) ( W before ) where W before and W after are the catalyst weights before and after synthesis, respectively. The carbon yields were statistically compared using Student’s t-test. 2.3 Characterization of CNTs and catalysts 2.3.1 CNT characterization The crystallinity of CNTs (I G/I D ratio) was measured with an N240-F Raman spectrometer (Nanoscope systems) using a 532 nm laser at 0.6 mW power, and the exposure time and the accumulation of the final spectrum were 7 s and 3 scans, respectively. The morphology of the synthesized CNTs was examined by SEM (GEMINI 500, ZEISS) at an acceleration voltage of 10 kV and a magnification of 30,000x, and by TEM (FEI Titan Cubed 60–300 with a Cs-Corrector and monochromator) at an acceleration voltage of 80 kV. The number of walls and outer diameter of the CNTs were measured by using Gatan DigitalMicrograph (ver. 3.11.0, Gatan Inc., USA) and ImageJ software (ver. 1.53 t, National Institutes of Health, USA), respectively. 2.3.2 Catalyst characterization The physical properties (specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter) were obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption test. Prior to the analysis, all samples (Al2O3 support, monometallic catalysts, and bimetallic catalysts) were pretreated at 300 ℃ for 4 h under vacuum. The adsorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K, and the pore size distribution was determined using the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method. The molecular structures of Al2O3 supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts were investigated by visible (vis-) and UV-Raman spectroscopy. Vis-Raman spectra were collected using a RAMAN touch (Bruker) equipped with a 532 nm excitation laser at a power of 3.09 mW. Each spectrum was recorded with an exposure time of 1 s and 7 accumulations. The spectra range spanned from 100 to 1200 cm−1. UV-Raman (325 nm, Renishaw inVia confocal Raman microscope) spectra were collected in the range of 400–1200 cm−1, and the exposure time and the accumulation of the final spectrum were 30 s and 10 scans, respectively. Conventional XRD spectra were acquired using a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) with a Cu Kα (wavelength = 1.5406 Å) radiation source. Angles ranging from 10° to 80° were collected with a step size of 0.0197° and a step time 1 s. XRD peak assignments were performed using the X’Pert HighScore Plus software (Malvern Panalytical), with the ICDD PDF-2 database employed as the reference for phase identification. Synchrotron X-ray diffraction (SXRD) analysis using synchrotron radiation was carried out at the 28-ID-1 PDF beamline of the National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS-II) at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), with an X-ray energy of 74.53 keV and a wavelength of 0.1665 Å. The samples were prepared in polyimide tubes (1 mm OD), and Dioptas software was used to extract one-dimensional (1D) SXRD data from two-dimensional (2D) scattering patterns [20]. The XPS measurements were performed on a AXIS SUPRA(Kratos Analytical). The Al Kα source (1486.6 eV) were used as excitation sources. O 1 s (530.8 eV) was taken as a reference to calculate the binding energies (Figure S3). The relative fractions of each metal’s oxidation states (Co and Mo) were calculated from the areas of the deconvoluted peaks. The metal loadings of the bimetallic catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Avio 550, PerkinElmer). Prior to measurement, the samples were digested in an acid solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The basic knowledge to predict metal oxide distribution in catalysts During the catalyst synthesis via the impregnation method, the surface charge of the support varies with the solution’s pH. At the PZC, the support surface carries no net electrical charge. It becomes negatively charged when the pH is above the PZC and positively charged when the pH is below it. When the support surface charge and metal ions possess opposite charges, strong electrostatic interactions arise, promoting efficient adsorption of the metal ions. Metal cations efficiently adsorb on a negatively charged surface through electrostatic interactions at pH exceeds the support’s PZC. These stronger interactions help to preserve the metal distribution formed during impregnation step throughout the subsequent stages such as drying and calcination, resulting in a well-dispersed metal phase on the support surface. We prepared bimetallic catalysts by varying the sequence of Co and Mo impregnated onto Al2O3. In one approach, we impregnated and heat-treated Co before adding Mo (step-CoMo); in another, we did the same with Mo first, then introduced Co (step-MoCo). To predict the distribution of metal oxides after the second impregnation, it is necessary to understand the state of the monometallic catalysts following the initial metal loading. Using the relationship between the PZC of the support and the pH of the metal precursor solution, we analyzed how a single metal (e.g., Co or Mo) distributes on Al2O3. When Co was dissolved in DI water, the pH of the precursor solution was ∼5.7, which is lower than the PZC of Al2O3 (8.6). Consequently, the Al2O3 surface becomes positively charged due to protonation ( Fig. 1(a)). Cobalt cations (Co+) adsorb onto Al2O3 but form weak interactions with the support. During heat treatment, they sintered and ultimately produced Co3O4 crystal with low dispersion. When Mo was impregnated, the pH of its precursor solution was measured to be 5.0, which was below the PZC of Al2O3, resulting in a positive surface charge. Under these conditions, molybdates ion are strongly adsorbed and maintained their distribution throughout heat treatment, leading to the formation of a well-dispersed molybdenum oxide (MoOx) layer (Fig. 1(b)) [21]. Preparation of bimetallic catalysts by impregnation requires not only considering how each metal ions interact with support but also how the metal ions interact with each other. The initially loaded metal can occupy active sites or alter the surface charge, thereby influencing the adsorption behavior or extent of the subsequently introduced metal. At the same time, electrostatic and other interactions between the metals can affect their oxidation states or distribution within the catalyst. Since CNT growth takes place on the metal generated by reducing metal oxides, these differences may ultimately influence both the catalyst’s performance in CNT synthesis and the properties of resulting CNTs [22]. 3.2 CNT synthesis results As a result of the CNT synthesis, the bimetallic catalysts showed higher carbon yields than the monometallic catalysts ( Fig. 2), which was confirmed to be statistically significant by Student’s t-test. The detailed t-test results are provided in the Table S1. Among them, stepwise-impregnated catalysts achieved higher carbon yields than the co-impregnated catalyst. In particular, the step-CoMo catalyst exhibited approximately five times the yield (1145 ± 52 %) of the CoMo catalyst (235 ± 9 %) and twice the yield of the step-MoCo catalyst (653 ± 22 %). To evaluate the performance of catalysts more comprehensively, the carbon yield achieved in this study was compared with those reported in previous studies under various conditions ( Table 1). Notably, the step-CoMo catalyst in this study exhibited the highest carbon productivity (about 1145 %/h), which is significantly greater than most reported value for CNT synthesis in the literature. Raman spectroscopy has been used to understand the structure of carbon-based materials, such as graphite, graphene, amorphous carbon, and CNTs [23,24]. Furthermore, the intensity ratios of the defect or disorder carbon band (D-band) and the graphitic carbon band (G-band) have been applied to understand the crystallite size (or amorphization) of carbon [25–28]. Based on the Raman spectra of synthesized CNTs and the calculated I G/I D ratio, no significant differences were observed, except for Mo, indicating that the impregnation sequence of bimetallic catalysts has minimal impact on the crystallinity of CNTs (Figure S4). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis confirmed no significant difference in CNT morphology depending on the sequence of metal loading (Figure S5). 3.3 Catalyst characterization Prior to phase analysis, the phase composition and textural properties of the Al2O3 support were examined as a reference. The textural properties of the mono- and bimetallic catalysts were also evaluated to trace the changes in surface area and porosity after each impregnation and calcination step, as summarized in Table 2. It was confirmed from the pore diameter distribution and the shape of the isotherms that all samples possess a mesoporous structure (pore size 1–50 nm) as shown in Figure S6. After metal impregnation and subsequent calcination, decreases in the specific surface area (SSA), total pore volume, and average pore diameter were observed for Al2O3. The pristine Al2O3 support possessed the largest surface area (208 m2/g), pore volume (0.439 cm3/g), and average pore diameter (7.30 nm). Upon Co impregnation, both the SSA and pore volume decreased to 148 m2/g and 0.317 cm3/g, respectively; however, the average pore diameter increased to 8.39 nm. The enlargement of pore size could be attributed either to the blocking of smaller pores during Co adsorption followed by drying and calcination, or to the decomposition of the Co nitrate precursor during calcination, where the released species such as NO3 - may have acted as pore-enlarging additives [32]. Subsequent Mo impregnation to obtain the step-CoMo catalyst resulted in decreases in SSA (128 m2/g), pore volume (0.212 cm3/g), and average pore diameter (5.43 nm). This can be ascribed to the adsorption of Mo species on the support surface, which upon thermal treatment formed by Mo oxide phases (including Mo-Al-O bonds), thereby partially blocking or narrowing the pores. By contrast, Mo impregnation alone led to decrease in SSA (180 m2/g), pore volume (0.334 cm3/g), and average pore diameter (6.17 nm). When Co was impregnated as the second metal in the preparation of the step-MoCo catalyst, Co cations were adsorbed on the hydrated MoOx layer, which is negatively charged [33], or on the Al2O3 pore surface. After calcination, these species transformed into CoMoOx and Co oxides, leading to pore blockage or surface coverage and consequently further reductions in SSA (150 m2/g), pore volume (0.223 cm3/g), and average pore diameter (4.77 nm). Although a larger specific surface area is generally associated with higher catalytic activity, the step-CoMo, which had the lowest surface area, exhibited the highest carbon yield in this study. This result indicates that, rather than the physical property of SSA, the distribution of metal species, phase formation, and metal-support interactions determined by the impregnation sequence play a much more crucial role in CNT synthesis. Therefore, elucidating the formation and distribution of metal phases is essential to understand how the impregnation sequence affects phase formation in the catalysts. Accordingly, phase analyses of the catalysts were performed in this work to substantiate this conclusion. It is hypothesized that the variation in carbon yield is attributed to the molecular and electronic structures of surface species (MoOx or CoOx), as CNTs are formed on metal particles, which may vary depending on the order of metal impregnation. Visible (532 nm) and UV (325 nm)-Raman spectroscopy were applied to determine the structure of surface species, and results are shown in Fig. 3. Because UV laser has a shorter wavelength, UV-Raman provides a relatively shallow penetration depth—on the order of a few nanometers—allowing for surface-sensitive analysis of the sample. On the other hand, vis-Raman penetrates deeper, up to several hundred nanometers, enabling the characterization of bulk features [34,35]. Based on the visible and UV-Raman spectra of the catalysts, we confirmed the presence of cobalt oxide (CoOx), cobalt molybdate (CoMoOx) and molybdenum oxide (MoOx) phases in the catalysts. It should be noted that Al2O3 support displayed no distinct bands at 100–1200 cm−1. For clarity, the Raman peak positions observed in this study and their corresponding species assignments are summarized in Table 3. Among the identified phases, CoMoOx and MoOx phases are intimately correlated with the carbon yields. Except for the Mo sample’s Raman spectrum, the Co, CoMo, step-MoCo, and step-CoMo samples’ visible-Raman spectra contain the four bands (e.g., ∼191, ∼464, ∼506, and ∼670 cm−1) in the range of 100–700 cm−1, which are attributed to Co3O4 [36]. In the case of the CoMo samples, the formation of CoMoOx is confirmed by ∼361, ∼811, ∼872, and ∼931 cm−1 peaks (Fig. 3(a)) [37,38]. Weak band at ∼934 cm−1 in the step-MoCo sample’s visible-Raman spectrum provides the trivial amounts of CoMoOx. The UV-Raman spectra of Mo, CoMo, step-MoCo, and step-CoMo samples confirm that surface species should be either CoMoOx or MoOx (Fig. 3(b)). It is worth noting that Co3O4 bands are absent in their UV-Raman spectra, suggesting that CoMoOx or MoOx is dominant on the catalyst surface. The UV-Raman spectra exhibited CoMoO4 bands in CoMo (∼817 and ∼939 cm−1) and step-MoCo (∼818 and ∼939 cm−1) spectra [37,38]. Although both CoMoOx and MoOx Raman peaks are located at similar Raman shift regions, based on the peak shape, it is concluded that the step-CoMo sample mainly possesses the MoOx surface species. Regarding the MoOx Raman bands, the peaks at ∼371 (Vis), ∼964 (Vis), and ∼948 (UV) cm−1 are assigned to isolated MoO4 species (referring here to monomeric isolated MoO4 units incorporated within phases such as Fe2(MoO4)3 and Al2(MoO4)3), whereas the peaks at ∼212 (Vis), ∼863 (Vis), and ∼848 (UV) cm−1 are assigned to polymerized MoOx [33,39]. The high intensity band at ∼950 cm−1 in the UV-Raman spectrum of the step-CoMo sample—close to the ∼948 cm−1 band of Mo—indicates that isolated MoO4 is the major species on the step-CoMo catalyst’s surface. Based on the visible and UV-Raman analyses, it is concluded that the step-CoMo sample contains relatively less CoMoO4 compared to the step-MoCo and CoMo samples. Consequently, the higher presence of isolated MoO4 and the lower presence of CoMoO4 are likely responsible for the superior carbon yields observed with step-CoMo. To determine the composition and crystalline structures of the bimetallic catalysts, XRD measurements were applied. Since conventional lab-scale XRD has difficulty distinguishing CoMoO4 from other MoOx species in the bimetallic samples as shown in Figure S7, SXRD was conducted to achieve higher resolutions ( Fig. 4 and Figure S9). In addition, the XRD pattern of the spent catalysts obtained after 30 s of CNT growth (Figure S8) showed significantly weakened metal-related peaks due to the coverage by CNTs, making phase identification difficult. In general, the fresh bimetallic samples show similar XRD patterns, with comparable relative amounts of CoMoO4 (PDF 00–021–0868) and Co3O4 (PDF 00–043–1003), as determined by comparing the intensities of their peaks, especially in the > 3.75° 2θ ranges. These results are well matched to the Raman results. In the case of the step-CoMo sample’s XRD pattern, however, only an Al2(MoO4)3 (PDF 01–084–1652) phase containing an isolated MoO4 structure was observed in the < 3.75° 2θ ranges. As shown in Fig. 2, the carbon yield of step-MoCo is higher than that of CoMo sample. Since both step-MoCo and CoMo do not contain the isolated MoO4 species, to understand the relationship between surface species and activity, intensity ratios (ICoMoO4/ICo3O4) of CoMoO4 (2θ = 2.83°) and Co3O4 (2θ = 3.90°) were evaluated: ICoMoO4/ICo3O4 (CoMo) ≈ 2.62 and ICoMoO4/ICo3O4 (step-MoCo) ≈ 0.86. In the case of the step-CoMo, although the most intense CoMoO4 peak overlapped with Al2(MoO4)3, ICoMoO4/ICo3O4 (step-CoMo) was ∼ 0.37, which showed the lowest among the bimetallic catalysts. These results confirm that the carbon yields correspond to the relative concentrations of the following surface species: Co3O4 > Al2(MoO4)3 > CoMoO4. The combined the Raman and XRD results indicate that both Co3O4 (bulk character) and Al2(MoO4)3 (surface species) are closely related to the enhancement of catalytic performance for carbon yields. To elucidate how the catalysts' surface oxidation states affect CNT growth, we performed XPS on the three bimetallic catalysts. Deconvolution of the Co 2p spectra revealed nearly similar Co2+/Co3+ ratios in all samples (Figure S10), in line with Raman and SXRD data that identified cobalt exclusively as Co3O4 and CoMoO4. By contrast, the Mo 3d spectra exhibited clear differences in surface oxidation states among the catalysts ( Fig. 5). In CoMo and step-MoCo, the Mo4+ doublets at 230.8 eV (3d5/2) and 234.0 (3d3/2) were exhibited, whereas the step-CoMo showed only Mo6+ doublets at 232.5 eV (3d5/2) and 235.6 eV (3d3/2) [40–42]. Mo4+ species were not observed in the Raman or SXRD results but were only detected by XPS. This indicates that Mo4+ does not exist in the bulk phase but rather is localized and confined to the surface of the CoMo and step-MoCo samples. In the step-MoCo case, the Mo precursor was directly impregnated onto the free Al2O3 surface, and the NH3 released during thermal decomposition of the precursor likely created a localized reducing environment, leading to the partial reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+, as evidenced by the XPS signal [43]. In contrast, in the step-CoMo sample, the prior impregnation of Co appears to have stabilized the Mo precursor through Co–O–Al or Co–Mo–O bonding environments. As a result, the reduction was suppressed, Mo was predominantly maintained in the Mo6+ state, and Al2(MoO4)3 species were preferentially formed. Correlating the XPS results with the Raman and SXRD indicates that step-CoMo exposes only Mo6+ phases—CoMoO4 and Al2(MoO4)3—at its surface, whereas CoMo and step-MoCo contained only small surface fractions of CoMoO4 (24.7 % and 5.9 %, respectively) together with MoO2. We found a negative correlation between CoMoO4 content and carbon yield, demonstrating the catalytic inactivity of CoMoO4 toward CNT growth. Considering this trend and the Mo oxidation-state differences revealed by XPS, we infer that the CNT productivity is maximized when Mo avoids alloying with cobalt oxides and remains dispersed as the Al2(MoO4)3 phase. 3.4 The effect of impregnation sequence on the carbon yield and surface species When using bimetallic catalysts for CNT synthesis at both 10 and 60 min, CoMo catalyst—which contained the largest amount of CoMoO4—showed the lowest carbon yield as shown in Fig. 2 and Figure S11. Based on the relationship between CoMoO4 peak intensity and carbon yield, we infer that the formation of CoMoO4 consumes active Co metal required for CNT synthesis. This consumption decreases the number of active sites, thereby leading to a lower carbon yield. The relationship between the formation of multi-walled (or single-walled) CNTs and Co-based surface species has been reported. It was observed that low-crystalline multi-walled CNTs (MWCNTs) are synthesized from large Co clusters formed by the reduction of Co3O4, whereas highly crystalline SWCNTs grow from small Co clusters generated by the reduction of CoMoO4 [7,44]. TEM images and diameter distribution ( Fig. 6a-d and Figure S12) confirm that most of the CNTs produced by the bimetallic catalysts are MWCNTs. Furthermore, regarding the CNT growth mechanism, it is widely accepted that CNTs predominantly grow via the vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) mechanism [45,46] In this process, carbon-containing gases dissolve into liquid metal particles at high temperature, and once the particles become saturated, carbon precipitates out to form solid CNTs. The particle size of the catalyst thus strongly affects the diameter of the resulting CNTs. In our study, TEM analysis revealed CNTs with diameters mainly in the range of 10–25 nm, suggesting that CNT growth was promoted by relatively large Co particles in which carbon dissolution and precipitation occurred. These results establish that Co3O4 serves as the active species for the multi-wall (7–17 no. of wall) formation. Because the order of metal impregnation affects specific sites where Mo (or MoOx) reacts or adsorbs, the amount of CoMoO4 formed varies accordingly. This phenomenon can be elucidated through the correlation between the PZC of the support and pH of the metal precursor solution ( Fig. 7). In the case of the CoMo catalyst, the Co cation and molybdate ions react to form hydrated CoMoO4 [44]. The resulting precursor solution has a measured pH of 4.7, which is lower than the PZC of Al2O3 (8.6), thereby causing the support surface to be positively charged. Consequently, the excess Co+ and the hydrated CoMoO4 on the Al2O3 surface are converted into Co3O4 and CoMoO4, respectively, after heat treatment. It is proposed that the rapid kinetics of CoMoO4 formation result in the majority of Mo in CoMo/Al2O3 existing as CoMoO4, with its concentration surpassing that of Co3O4 species (Fig. 7(a)). In the case of the step-MoCo catalysts, adding MoOx/Al2O3 to a solution containing dissolved Co precursors (pH = 5.0) results in a positively charged Al2O3 surface. Since the MoOx layer on the Al2O3 surface acquires a negative charge through hydration in solution, it enables Co cation adsorption onto the MoOx site via electrostatic interactions. During heat treatment, CoMoO4 is formed, while the remaining Co transforms into Co3O4 (Fig. 7(b)). Since only the Co cation adsorbed onto the MoOx layer can convert into CoMoO4, step-MoCo contains less CoMoO4 than CoMo. The proposed synthesis mechanisms are corroborated by the results from Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 3(a)) and XRD patterns (Fig. 4). In the case of step-CoMo catalyst, Co is first impregnated onto Al2O3, resulting in the formation of Co3O4. During the subsequent Mo impregnation step, both Al2O3 (PZC ≈ 8.6) and Co3O4 (PZC ≈ 7.3–7.5) surfaces are positively charged [47,48] Since the measured pH of the Mo precursor solution is 5.0—lower than PZC of Al2O3 and Co3O4—their surface becomes positively charged. But the higher surface charge density of Al2O3 (ΔpH ≈ 3.6) compared to Co3O4 (ΔpH ≈ 2.3–2.5) leads to stronger electrostatic adsorption of molybdate ion onto Al2O3. As a result, molybdates ion preferentially adsorb onto the positively charged Al2O3 rather than Co3O4, and form Al2(MoO4)3 after heat treatment step (Fig. 7(c)). Based on the proposed synthesis mechanisms, it is reasonable to hypothesize that in the step-CoMo sample, a large fraction of Mo remains as Al2(MoO4)3, leading to less CoMoO4 formation compared to other bimetallic catalysts. The metal contents of Co and Mo in the bimetallic catalysts were compared using ICP-OES analysis ( Table 4). Among the three catalysts, the co-impregnated CoMo exhibited the lowest overall metal loading, whereas the catalysts prepared by stepwise impregnation showed relatively higher Co and Mo contents, clearly reflecting the effect of impregnation sequence on loading efficiency. The particularly low metal content in the co-impregnated CoMo can be attributed to the facile formation of electrically neutral CoMoO4 species in solution, which arises from the reaction between Co2+ and MoO4 2- precursors. Because these neutral species interact weakly with the Al2O3 support surface, they are not effectively adsorbed and are subsequently lost during calcination, resulting in reduced final metal loading. In contrast, the stepwise impregnation catalysts exhibited significantly higher metal loadings than the co-impregnated sample. This is because the first impregnated metal forms a stable oxide phase during calcination, anchoring it to the support, and the subsequently introduced metal is adsorbed on this stabilized surface. In the case of step-MoCo, Mo initially binds to Al2O3 and forms a MoOx layer, onto which Co cations are later electrostatically adsorbed due to the negatively charged hydrated MoOx layer. Conversely, in step-CoMo, Co cations initially encounter electrostatic repulsion from the support surface but are stabilized upon calcination through transformation into Co3O4. The subsequently introduced Mo species are then adsorbed on both the Co3O4 phase and the support surface, minimizing metal loss. As a result, both stepwise-impregnated catalysts retained higher overall metal loadings. Therefore, the enhanced metal retention achieved by stepwise impregnation effectively increases the concentration of catalytically active Co species for CNT growth, which explains the superior catalytic performance of step-MoCo and step-CoMo compared with the co-impregnated CoMo. The preserved Co by the stepwise impregnation enhances the catalytic performance through a synergistic effect with MoOx species. In the case of bimetallic catalysts containing Co and Mo, it has been reported that MoOx transforms into a carbide phase during CNT synthesis. This transformation provides carbon to the Co metal in a stable manner, prevents its sintering at elevated temperature, and enables continuous CNT growth [10,49]. Based on activity and characterization results, controlling the reaction rate, suppressing CoOx sintering in the presence of MoOx, and maximizing the stability of Co3O4 are crucial for enhancing carbon yields. Among the bimetallic catalysts, step-CoMo most effectively meets these requirements because it predominantly retains MoOx in the form of Al2(MoO4)3, while minimizing the formation of CoMoO4. This ensures the preservation of the largest amount of Co3O4, thereby achieving the highest carbon yield. By contrast, the exclusive reliance on Co3O4 as the active species cannot fully explain the discrepancies in carbon yield, specifically the highest yield observed with step-CoMo and the lowest yield with Co monometallic sample, as shown in Fig. 2. It should be re-emphasized that the Co monometallic sample, despite containing only Co3O4, exhibited a lower carbon yield than inactive CoMoO4-containing bimetallic catalysts. Under the given CNT formation conditions, CoOx (e.g., Co3O4) in the Co catalyst tends to undergo sintering and rapid deactivation, which hinders the ability to effectively regulate the decomposition rate of C2H4 (carbon source). In summary, the structure–activity relationship can be described as follows: Co3O4 serves as the active species for CNT growth, CoMoO4 acts as an inactive phase that consumes Co, and Al2(MoO4)3 functions as a promoter that suppresses Co sintering and thereby enhances the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions In this study, we investigated how the impregnation order of metal precursors affects the formation of surface species (e.g., CoMoO4, Co3O4, MoO4) on Al2O3 and the resulting carbon yields, elucidating the relationship between these factors. The stepwise-impregnated catalysts (e.g., step-CoMo and step-MoCo) exhibited higher carbon yields compared to those prepared by co-impregnated catalyst (CoMo). The step-CoMo catalyst—prepared by impregnating Mo after Co—achieved the highest carbon yields, despite having the lowest specific surface area (128 m2/g). Characterization of the catalysts using SXRD and visible- and UV-Raman spectroscopy revealed an inverse correlation between the amount of CoMoO4 and the CNT yields. In addition, XPS showed that step-CoMo with the highest CNT productivity are dominated by fully oxidized Mo6+ species, whereas the lower-yield catalysts (CoMo and step-MoCo) contains Mo6+ incorporated into CoMoO4 together with a large fraction of Mo4+ contribution from MoO2, indicating that keeping Mo from combining with cobalt oxides is critical for maximizing carbon productivity. TEM images and the crystallinity of CNTs confirmed the presences of MWCNTs, indicating that CoMoO4 has a negligible effect. The variation in CoMoO4 content arises from differences in the interaction between Co cation and molybdate ion with the support or previously impregnated metal oxides, which are ultimately governed by the order and number of impregnation step. The formation rate of CoMoO4 follows the trend: CoMo > step-MoCo > step-CoMo. ICP-OES analysis further confirmed that stepwise impregnation leads to higher Co and Mo loadings than co-impregnation, which enhances the retention of catalytically active species and contributes to superior CNT productivity. This result can be explained by the relationship between the pH of the metal precursor solutions and the PZC of the support. The current fundamental studies highlight the importance of considering adsorption behavior of metal ions on support during catalyst preparation as a crucial factor for enhancing carbon yields. coredata.dc:description: Supported bimetallic catalysts are widely used for carbon nanotube (CNT) synthesis, yet the effects of impregnation procedure remain underexplored. Here, we investigated how the sequence of metal impregnation affects CNT synthesis. We prepared cobalt-molybdenum (Co-Mo) bimetallic catalysts on alumina supports via co- and stepwise impregnation, then compared their CNT synthesis performance under identical conditions. Stepwise-impregnated catalysts exhibited higher carbon yields than those prepared by co-impregnation. Notably, impregnating Mo after Co achieved the highest yield despite the lowest BET surface area. Synchrotron X-ray diffraction and visible/UV-Raman spectroscopy revealed that only this catalyst contained Al2(MoO4)3 with a MoO4 structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy clarified the surface chemistry: the catalyst with the highest CNT productivity exposed Mo entirely as Mo6 + in Al2(MoO4)3 and CoMoO4, whereas the others contained both Mo4+ and Mo6+. The MoOx species like Al2(MoO4)3 is known to suppress Co sintering during CNT synthesis, delaying catalyst deactivation and enhancing the carbon yield. Moreover, an inverse relationship was observed between carbon yield and the CoMoO4 content. This is attributed to the consumption of catalytically active Co during CoMoO4 formation, which reduces active sites for CNT growth. ICP-OES further confirmed higher Co and Mo loadings for stepwise catalysts, contributing to superior catalyst performance. The extent of CoMoO4 formation strongly depended on the metal introduction sequence. This trend is illustrated by considering the relationship between the point of zero charge of support and the pH of the metal precursor solutions.
